title: `lighthouse` cannot get deposit data from `erigon`
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: `2021.08.2-alpha`

OS & Version: ArchLinux (up-to-date)

Commit hash: dfa2800a6ddf63ef9c7f6284fb6535b0f214736f

#### Expected behaviour

The `lighthouse` beacon node worked fine with `openethereum`, so I hoped it would work fine with `erigon` as well.

#### Actual behaviour

The `lighthouse` beacon node can’t get deposits from Eth1. I tried to wipe out `lighthouse`’s data and let it re-sync, but that didn’t help.

Before the wipeout:
```
lighthouse[1012595]: Aug 09 06:10:40.712 ERRO Failed to update eth1 cache             error: Failed to update eth1 deposit cache: "FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 205886, expected: 204947 })", retry_millis: 60000, service: eth1_rpc
```

After the wipeout:
```
lighthouse[1513063]: Aug 09 06:56:19.940 ERRO Failed to update eth1 cache             error: Failed to update eth1 deposit cache: "FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 200598, expected: 0 })", retry_millis: 60000, service: eth1_rpc
```

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Not really sure. This is how I run the processes involved:

```
erigon \
    --datadir=/var/lib/erigon/erigon \
    --ethash.dagdir=/var/lib/erigon/erigon-ethash \
    --prune=hrtc \
    --metrics \
    --metrics.addr=[::1] \
    --metrics.port=12797 \
    --private.api.addr=[::1]:10090
```

```
rpcdaemon \
    --datadir=/var/lib/erigon/erigon \
    --http.addr=[::1] \
    --http.api=eth,erigon,web3,net,debug,trace,txpool,shh \
    --http.vhosts=my.domain.name \
    --metrics \
    --metrics.addr=[::1] \
    --metrics.port=12794 \
    --private.api.addr=[::1]:10090
```

```
lighthouse bn \
    --datadir /var/lib/lighthouse/beacon \
    --http \
    --eth1 \
    --eth1-endpoints http://my.domain.name:8545 \
    --block-cache-size 256 \
    --target-peers 128 \
    --metrics \
    --metrics-port 12795
```

#### Backtrace

N/A, there is no crash.
@andrejpodzimek , you can add `--verbosity=4` to RPCDaemon - to see all incoming requests from lighthouse.

So I’ve set `--verbosity 4`. For example, for this on the `lighthouse` side…

```
Aug 09 13:55:11 lighthouse[2176284]: Aug 09 13:55:11.739 ERRO Failed to update eth1 cache             error: Failed to update eth1 deposit cache: "FailedToInsertDeposit(NonConsecutive { log_index: 200607, expected: 0 })", retry_millis: 60000, service: eth1_rpc
```

…this appears around the same time on the `rpcdaemon` side:

```
Aug 09 13:55:11 rpcdaemon[2173745]: [DBUG] [08-09|13:55:11] Served                                   conn=[::1]:45948 t=1.761915ms method=eth_getBlockByNumber reqid=1 params="[\"latest\",false]"
Aug 09 13:55:11 rpcdaemon[2173745]: [DBUG] [08-09|13:55:11] Served                                   conn=[::1]:45950 t=2.446303ms method=eth_getLogs reqid=1 params="[{\"address\":\"0x00000000219ab540356cbb839cbe05303d7705fa\",\"fromBlock\":\"0xc4d8ac\",\"toBlock\":\"0xc4dc94\",\"topics\":[\"0x649bbc62d0e31342afea4e5cd82d4049e7e1ee912fc0889aa790803be39038c5\"]}]"
```

It’s retried every minute, but to no avail. The `fromBlock` and `toBlock` numbers don’t change.

Earlier there’s a thick cloud of requests where `fromBlock` and `toBlock` _do_ change, but these are only `eth_getLogs` calls (and no `eth_getBlockByNumber`). Unlike the errors above [1 retry per minute], these queries are frequent; here’s one second worth of those:

But eventually this^^^ stops and only the errors with 1 retry per minute stay around.

(The outgoing [`lighthouse`] / incoming [`rpcdaemon`] ports differ, because `lighthouse` never reuses a TCP connection and keeps reconnecting, even during its initialization with lots of queries. Not a huge deal on `::1`, but it’s somewhat ugly still.)

A wild guess: Could this be the problem? `--prune=hrtc`

If so, what should I stop pruning to (1) make the deposit queries from Eth2 work but (2) avoid a huge data size increase?

What would happen if I disabled some of the pruning options? Would a “partial re-sync” of some sort occur or would I have to delete the data directory and sync again? (This is somewhat hypothetical; I still don’t know if pruning is to blame and which pruning options to disable.)

@andrejpodzimek , i don't know how much data lighthouse will request. In your requests:
```
fromBlock":"0xc27364
```
maybe it start from this block, maybe earlier. 

In my understanding ProofOfStake works based on Receipts/Logs - this is reason why lighthouse calling eth_getLogs
And likely there is no "fixed" point, but it need logs from last validator set election (or similar event).

We have feature-request to not prune data by distance, but keep up to some block number:  https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/issues/2421 - but I didn't work on it. 

I advise to keep last 500K receipts: `--prune=hrtc --prune.r.older=500_000` (or even 1_000_000)
by default it keeps last 90K
Or keep all receipts, by removing `r` from pruning.

Erigon doesn't allow change --prune settings to avoid human mistakes. 
Can change it by `./build/bin/integration set_prune --datadir=<datadir> --prune=htc`

Of course changing pruning option will not re-generate for you old data, and it will just stop deleting - and to get through  300K blocks will take 4 weeks, unless litehouse will not need old data anymore.

`h` character in --prune means no far history indices, means can't re-execute historical blocks after this threshold to re-generate receipts. 
So, after change your --prune mode, you can update lighthouse and wait, maybe new validator set election will happen. If not, then likely you need re-sync.

Actually, IIUC from #2421, I would need to keep ~2_000_000 receipts to get to the needed “Eth2 genesis” block and, once that block eventually gets pruned, I would then be unable to re-sync `lighthouse` again. So most likely a removal of `r`  is the way to go. I’ll just try that and re-sync; no big deal. Hopefully this won’t cause a data size explosion. That may be some extra data, but if it enables me to re-sync `lighthouse` (if anything goes wrong with it), then that’s a plus.

In any case, +1 for the `--prune.*.before` feature, which I didn’t known I needed up until now.

+300 GB is feasible with my current storage.

```
erigon[532516]: [INFO] [08-10|12:40:29] Effective                                prune="--prune=htc"
```

Alright, this^^^ looks promising. Now I hope I needed to remove _either_ `h` _or_ `r`, not both. :grimacing: Or else I’ll have one more full re-sync to do.

So it seems to be working with `--prune=htc` instead of `--prune=hrtc`. `lighthouse` is syncing and doesn’t complain about anything now.

But the size increase … oh, the size increase. It would be awesome to have some sort of safe pruning, as #2421 suggests.

Another idea: Maybe I could switch `r` pruning in `erigon` **on** again once `lighthouse` gets in sync. (?) What I don’t entirely understand is whether `lighthouse` stops asking about old blocks after its syncing gets past them or whether it can, in theory, keep asking about them **forever**.

In the former case, I would quite happily sacrifice the ability to re-sync `lighthouse` from scratch and enable `r` in `erigon`’s pruning. (I guess this must be done “offline”, using `integration set_prune --prune=hrtc ...`, right?) But then if `lighthouse` starts complaining again, I’ll be re-syncing everything again. 😭

About `integration set_prune --prune=hrtc ...` - I advise do not use much integration tool unless you really know what you are doing. For example even if you enable prune now - it will delete receipts just fine - but db will not get smaller, it only will stop growth for long time. And maybe - but very unlikely - will shrink a bit in far future. It's nature of LMDB/MDBX databases.   

Another option - find correct value of --prune.r.older=... to make lighthouse happy. 

Another option - zfs with enabled compression - shows 2x compression ratio on Erigon's db (and increasing RAM consumption and Disk IO).

I'm fairly certain that the calls are for eth_getLogs so that it can see deposits from the eth1 chain. And since you already got the logs, it should be fine to prune them so long as you're never offline longer than the prune threshold for those logs.

Yes, it works. I had a Btrfs snapshot with `--prune=hrtc`, so I snapshotted the `htc` version, restored the `hrtc` one, waited for it to re-sync again, started `lighthouse` again and … it works. The data size is _way_ smaller and `lighthouse` is in sync. I wouldn’t be able to sync `lighthouse` from scratch in this configuration, but at least now I know how to get there if need be.

There are two easy ideas for `--prune hrtc` and syncing LH from scratch.

1) If Erigon is not yet synced, give LH a failover Infura node. `--eth1-endpoints http://erigon-IP:8545,https://InfuraURL`. It will grab what it needs from Infura, and by the time Erigon is done syncing, LH just needs to get new deposit data from it.
2) If Erigon is already synced, switch LH between Infura and Erigon. Start with `--eth1-endpoints https://InfuraURL`, then once deposit data is in, start LH again with `--eth1-endpoints http://erigon-IP:8545,https://InfuraURL`. Exact same procedure if you ever have to remove LH's "eth1 cache".

That said, yes: I'd love a `--prune.*.before` in Erigon.

Unfortunately, the `--eth1-endpoints` trick has no effect, i.e., one cannot switch to Infura and back. The eth1 endpoint is most likely stored somewhere in the LH database. Attempts to switch to Infura do exactly nothing.

This means that while one _can_ bootstrap LH from scratch using Infura, there is _no way_ to switch (back) to a local Erigon. This all-or-nothing setup LH insists on is very annoying.

It is however entirely possible to sync an Erigon that has the requisite logs, by using prune.r.before. Eth-docker has an entrypoint script with the values for Prater and mainnet if you want to take a peek. 

I recommend closing this issue. Prune.*.before is now a thing and solves it.
